--- In gladiator@egroups.com, "Tom Tildrum" <Tevildo@h...> wrote:
>      Based on what I know of the C-type languages, the problem could 
be the 
> range of numbers you're working with. Depending on how much memory 
the coder 
> wanted to take up with each value, there are a set number of memory 
> locations where the value sits. If it grows larger than the space 
allocated 
> for it, the overflow is discarded.... or if it intrudes on another 
value, 
> perhaps one used to run Glad.exe or Windows, you get a nice crash. 
To make 
> things worse, at one end of your little rented space in memory 
there's a bit 
> which tells the computer whether the number is positive or negative. 
If the 
> value gets too high, it overflows into this area and you usually get 
a 
> negative. That's what I assume happened to our archmages.

I did a trial run with friendly slime help above experience level 250 
and every time the slime had negative values for both health and magic 
energy.  Since I have defeated slime with experience level above 1000, 
I know it is possible.
>      One thing that I'm not quite sure on--which of your levels are 
so 
> difficult? I can beat any of the ones you posted with a character 
below 
> level 75. (Of course, the experience gained on the level usually 
puts me 
> above 100.) I think that perhaps you should be steering yourself 
away from 
> the this-is-a-job-for-SuperMage(TM) scenarios and make something 
with a more 
> universal appeal.

I promise the ones I publish can be defeated with a legitimate team.  
I am steering myself to slowly increase experience levels of 
characters.  Afterall, Extreme Island is about a training ground for 
characters.  The planned ending is . . . interesting.  But the pace 
will be slow.  At tops, I plan on placing maybe 24 experience level 
50s or higher (excluding slime) in future scenarios, but they will be 
the only high experience level character in that scenario.  Normal 
characters will top out with experience levels between 20 and 25 or 
lower.  I have at most 2 or 3 more scenarios with level 10s, then 
about 10 with level 15s, 10 with level 20s, and 10 more with level 
25s.  I am shifting downward the number of characters in each scenario 
towards around 50 or so.

If you want to see my scenarios which have so called gods in them, 
email me and I will send them to you.  Believe me when I tell you that 
they make all other of my other scenarios seem like the 1st 2-3 built 
into the game.  Otherwise, they stay on home computer for my private 
collection.  I am tempted to email to you, Tevildo, the scenario I 
have created that gives you 1.6 billion in gold, just so you can get 
sense about what I am talking about when I sa at certain experience 
levels, you can see the limits of character types.

While I am at, let me explain why I have a 1.6 billion dollar 
scenario.  This scenario is for the sole person of allowing me to 
create an experience level 100 or higher character to test out in 
certain situations.  There was just enough money to bring a beginning 
archer to experience level 220.
>      As for the rocks--I've had very large areas filled almost 
completely 
> with those rocks that never vanish, and unless you're a cleric, 
blob, or 
> orc, you can clear them out in a few minutes. Try an archer's 
barrage, or 
> just blast away with a mage or archmage. Those rocks will vanish.
>      I'm still having problems with chain lightning. Used correctly, 
without 
> pushing any limits, it still brings my computer to a crawl. It's a 
nice 
> chance to go get a drink, but it disrupts the role-playing realism. 
A lot. I 
> don't know how it's coded, but it may be that there are some 
unnecessary 
> calculations being done, slowing everything up. Or... is there a C 
object 
> for each little bolt of lightning? Blech. There must be SOME way to 
make the 
> lightning AI centralised... it's not my area of expertise so I won't 
try to 
> figure it out.

I agree wholeheartedly with you about chain lightning.  Even with a 
modest (30 characters) amount of opponents, chain lightning can 
severely cripple the game.  While I am talking about chain lightning, 
I have a complaint against hearburts attacks.  I froze time with a 
mage and used heartburst attack against opponents until I ran out of 
energy and did not kill any.  However, against the same opponents, my 
mage's basic attack killed them all with energy to spare.  That is 
something I have observed about mages with high experience levels:  
the heartburst attack is spread out so much that in small scenarios, 
it affects ALL opponents.

DPH
